Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE - LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and his staff are gathered around a table, playing poker. C.J. is dealing the cards.

Dialogues.Line: Nine, no help. Jack, no help. Eight, possible flush. King, possible flush. Ace, no help. Six, possible straight. Dave of love for the dealer. Ace bets.
There is one fruit... The President's staff groans.
Mr. President, check or bet sir. Those are your choices.
Or you should feel free to give us a quiz on inane trivia.
There is one fruit whose seeds are on the outside. Name it please.
I see it. And I raise you five.
Well, thank you sir. I just raised your bet.
Yes you did Toby, and I thought it was a bold move when you consider that Leo's holding the six you're looking for.
Do you call the raise sir?
There are fourteen punctuation marks in Standard English grammar. Can anyone name them please?
That's only seven. There are seven more.
Question mark, exclamation point, quotation marks, brackets, parentheses, braces and ellipsis.
Do you call the raise sir?
There are three words, and three words only in the English language that begin with the letters DW.
This is a pretty good illustration of why we get nothing done. All laugh.
Can anyone name them for me please?
Three words that begin with DW?
Yes. Everyone mumbles out different words.
[to Sam] C'mon Princeton. We've got dwindle, we've got dwarf.
I see you five and raise you five by the way.
'Witches brew a magic spell, in an enchanted forest where fairies...'
Dwell! Dwell, dwell! Dwindle, dwarf and dwell!
Well, the answer's correct but let's check with our judges and -- oh no, I'm sorry, time's expired.
You have your own time? Everyone laughs.
Take your money sir. You'd dwell to report that to the I.R.S., report you as I will.
All right, I'm done. I'm gonna head home.
Yeah, I will. The staff begins to leave.
Sam, I'm going back to the office, they've got the commerce report ready for me. What are you doing?
Sam, I'm going back to the office, they've got the commerce report ready for me. What are you doing?
I'm going to go back to your office with you and make sure you understand the commerce report.

When I get through with you you're gonna know everything there is to know about standard data versus sampling data in the census. Bartlet and Leo walk into THE OVAL OFFICE. Charlie is seated on the couch.
Charlie, I'm headed over to the residence, you're done for the night.
Thank you sir. I'm gonna stay a bit to do some paperwork.
Don't stay up too late son.
[to Mandy as they walk in] How'd you do?
Most of that's mine. A door closes somewhere...
What's that? Suddenly several Secret Service Agents burst into THE OVAL OFFICE.
Excuse me Mr. President. I'm sorry the building's not secure. Would everyone stay in the room please? Sam and Josh are let in by another agent.
This is happening way too often.
It's pledge week at the fraternities. The kids hop the fence.
Would you mind stepping away from the doors and windows please?
This whole room is doors and windows.
This will be under control in just a minute, Mr. President.
All right. [long pause] What body of water in South America is formed by the confluence...?
Excuse me Wink Martindale? Do you really think this is the time?
Not quite up on your South American geography are you my friend?
This is exactly the kind of thing that didn't used to happen at my old job.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby walks in. Cathy and Bonnie are in their desks.

Dialogues.Line: Cathy, I need a copy of Article 1, Section 2.
Is that something I'm supposed to have at my desk?
Does anybody have a copy of the Constitution? [No one responds.] This is discouraging.
Bonnie, would you get Toby a copy of the Constitution?
Oh for crying out loud! Try Amazon.COM. If they don't have it then just bust into the glass display case at the National Archives!
[comes up from behind] You shouldn't yell.
Is it still in print, is what my staff would like to know.
It's not a big deal, I'm just, you know, here to see him about something.
Absolutely no reason that you should.
Okay. Toby walks into his office as C.J. walks into SAM'S OFFICE. Sam is busy talking on the phone.

[into phone] ...And the President's committed to vetoing any Commerce Bill that prohibits sampling data as a legitimate component of the 2000 Census, and I'm not saber rattling Jill, I'm just giving you a preview of what you're gonna get later with Toby. Yeah. I'll see you then. [hangs up and sees C.J.] Hey.
Hey. That was all great... what you just said there.
Not so much what you said, but the way you said it.
The census has to be taken seriously.
You know... It's not glamorous, but you know.
What do you need C.J.? The two start walking from the office to the HALLWAY.
Sam, I read my briefing book last night on the commerce bill regarding the census and there are certain parts of it I don't understand.
I can help you out. Which parts?
C.J., we've been working on this commerce bill for three weeks, I hear you talk about the census all the time.
Well...I don't understand. How could you-?

I've been playing it fast and loose there's no doubt about it, but sitting in on some of the meetings we've been having, and reading the briefing book last night, I have to say that the census is starting to sound to me like it's, well, important.
And, I've come to the realization that if I'm gonna be talking about it all week, it's probably best that I understand what I'm saying.
When did you come to this realization?
Okay. Let's... I tell you what, let's forget the fact that you're coming a little late to the party and embrace the fact that you showed up at all.
I know. I probably shouldn't do that.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh is standing at a file cabinet. Donna comes up from behind him.

Dialogues.Line: Can I ask you a question?
There's a 30 billion dollar budget surplus.
It'll actually shake out to about 32 billion.
Well, you know what they say?
A billion dollars here, a billion dollars there. Sooner or later it starts to add up to real money.
I didn't coin it or anything.
We have a 32 billion dollar surplus for the first time in three decades.
Republicans in Congress want to use this money for tax relief right?
Essentially what they're saying is, they wanna give back the money.
Why don't we wanna give back the money?
But it's not the government's money!
Sure it is. It's right there in our bank account.
That's only because we collected more money than we ended up needing.
I didn't think so. Josh and Donna enter LEO'S OFFICE. Toby, Cathy, Mandy, Sam and Leo are gathered there. They are reading the Appropriations Bill.

Twelve million dollars to establish an Appalachian transportation institute. 1.5 million to study parking facilities at commercial truck stops. Three million dollars to produce a documentary on highway infrastructure. These are just some of today's additions to the Appropriations Bill. And that's just in the area of transportation.
Two million dollars for a volcano monitor in Alaska to warn passing airplanes about ash?
By the way, the FAA doesn't know what that is!
550,000 dollars for New York State to restore the home of Susan B. Anthony.
While we're at it, the tile in my shower could use re-grouting.
Could somebody please remind me what's in this for us?
Power zones, US rail, and Federal funding for 100,000 new public school teachers.
We have a meeting with Gladman and Skinner, and they represent two of the three swing votes on the Commerce Committee.
Swing votes in terms of the census?
Yes. And if they agree to drop the sampling prohibition, the Appropriations Bill could pass without a problem.
You said three swing votes... Gladman, Skinner...
Presumably he's gonna do what he's told.
Tomorrow's the start of a three-day weekend and 435 congressmen want to make their flights home in the morning.
Oh, I know that'll do it.
Just don't do anything to screw up or in any way embarrass me okay?
Leo. Knute Rockne. Sometimes I get them mixed up.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and the head of the Secret Service, RON BUTTERFIELD, are seated on the couch.

Dialogues.Line: If they hop the fence, they're going to jail. What they do once we get to them is what's gonna determine for how long.
Well, there are alarms in the ground. [pointing to a map on the coffee table] Here, here, here here, here, here, and here. She tripped it here.
No sir. It was a mentally unbalanced woman in her forties.
Well, you know, just trying to kill me isn't necessarily evidence of being mentally unbalanced!
Sir, it appears from her statement...you weren't the target.
He says it was a woman!
We're still reviewing the frame-by-frame, Leo.
I'll get a report first thing?
Yes sir. Mr. President, if I could excuse myself to the outer office I could make a call and see...
Of course. [to Leo] This woman was after Zoey? Ron leaves.
There were eight security checks between where the woman was and Zoey's bedroom.
There's no need for Zoey to know about this right?

This may be the wrong time Mr. President, but I wanted to speak to you about... As the game was breaking up last night, you mentioned I should say hello to Jenny. Ron Butterfield walks back into the room.
Hang on a second. What've you got Ron?
You'll be happy to know our security system worked exactly the way our security system's supposed to work.
I'll see you in an hour sir.
[to Leo] All right, thanks. [to Butterfield] I guess we're done too. Leo leaves.
I wouldn't lose a lot of sleep over it sir.
Okay. Thank you. Ron Butterfield leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Mandy and Josh are seated inside pouring coffee. Congressmen GLADMAN, SKINNER and JOE WILLIS walk in.

Dialogues.Line: Mandy, if I'd known you were going to be here I would have brought my sword and shield.
Champagne and flowers would've done the trick.
She passed away last month, so I've taken over her seat in Congress.
Yes sir, we know. We're so sorry for your loss.
The White House sent flowers and the President wrote a very beautiful note. I wonder if you could pass along my thanks.

Please, no, I'm not a congressman. I teach 8th grade social studies. This is only temporary so... Toby enters with entourage. Cathy and two other staffers are with him. They have with them a bunch of copies of the Appropriations Bill.

Morning. Everyone got fruit. Everyone got bagels. Good, good. Christopher, Anthony, would you mind putting my copy of the Appropriations Bill on the table please. Thank you Christopher, thank you Anthony, and thank you Cathy. Gentlemen, why don't we take our seats? Congressman Skinner, welcome. Congressman Gladman, always good to have you here, sir. Congressman Willis, I was a great fan of your late wife.

This represents the latest draft of the House Appropriations Bill. It is 7,000 pages long, and weighs over 55 pounds. It includes 1.2 million dollars for a lettuce geneticist in Salinas, California and 1.7 million dollars for manure handling in Starkville, Mississippi.
Toby, you know that's what happens.
Eight states will divide 5 million dollars to research the uses of wood.
I'm thinking of some uses for it right now.
I thought we were here to talk about the census?
We are. The White House just wanted to take this opportunity to point out that you're criminals and despots.
But that's not going to stop the President from signing the bill into law?
No, sadly it won't. What will stop the President from signing the bill is the amendment your committee is offering on the census.

The three of you represent the swing vote on the Commerce Committee. You drop the census amendment and the Appropriations Bill goes through without a hitch. Insist on the law prohibiting sampling and you can count on a long floor fight followed by an almost certain veto.

I would like to emphasize the long floor fight of it all, and remind you that I have absolutely no conscience when it comes to exploiting the fact that you have non- refundable airline tickets for the weekend. With that in mind...
I'm not leaving town this weekend. I was gonna stay and see some of Janice's friends. So, there's no need to rush on my account. You can take as much time as you like.

Scenes.Description: C.J. and Sam are walking towards her office.

Dialogues.Line: And you're gonna go slowly right?
Pretend for the purposes of this conversation that I'm dumb.
Let me try to conjure an image of you as a stupid person.
You're cracking wise. I'm coming to you exposed and vulnerable.
This is your office. I'm coming to you.
Ah. They enter C.J.'S OFFICE and both sit.
I'm a person saying there's something I do not know, will you teach me. It's hard to admit you don't know something. That makes me submissive.
What is it exactly that you're asking me to do?
I'm admitting to you that there are things I do not know.
And I'm telling you that I don't think anybody would have any trouble imagining that there are things you do not know.
The Constitution mandates that every ten years we count everybody.

Because representation at the various levels of the government, federal, state and municipal, is based on population. The only way to find out how many congressmen California gets is to count the people in California. Got it?
Can I just say that if the briefing book had been written that clearly, I would have easily understood?

The decennial census has always been done by a door-to-door head count. Some 950,000 professionals are hired. The process costs approximately 6.9 billion dollars. The process is also very inaccurate. It tends to be significantly disadvantageous to inner city populations, recent immigrant populations, and of course the homeless.
You are a very good teacher, Sam. I want you to know that in this...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo walks in to find Mallory there.

Dialogues.Line: No. I just wanted to bring you some stuff from home.
Oh, you didn't have to do that.
I wanted you to have some stuff that you like.
I wanted Mom to have the house.
But you're gonna look for a place right? I can help you out on the weekends.
Mallory, this thing with your mother and me... it'll blow over.
No, it won't Dad. You understand that right?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby, Josh, Mandy, and the three congressmen are still discussing the census.

Dialogues.Line: This is a purely partisan issue Mandy. The Democrats want to win back the house!
I'm not gonna deny that there's something for us to gain. Donna comes in and whispers something to Josh.
No, no, no. It's like you lost the battle but now you want to win. Skinner's voice fades out as Donna and Josh leave the room to the HALLWAY. Donna and Josh begin another walk and talk.
Did he say what it was about?
No. What's wrong with me getting my money back?

Let's say your cut of the surplus is $700. I want to take your money, combine it with everyone else's money and use it to pay down the debt and further endow social security. What do you want to do with it?
But my $700 is helping to employ the people who manufacture and sell DVD players, not to mention the people who manufacture and sell DVDs. It's the natural evolution of the market economy.
The problem is, the DVD player you buy might be made in Japan.
You shouldn't have voted for us. Donna walks away, and Josh walks inside the OUTER OVAL OFFICE. He sees Charlie and Mrs. Landingham.
Mrs. Landingham, I got a message he needed to see me?
Yeah, go on in. Josh walks into THE OVAL OFFICE. Several people are in the room. Bartlet is on the phone.
[to the phone] Yes. Yes. Of course. [to Josh] I'm on a conference call with the postmaster general.
Look, I want you to do me a favor.
Take Charlie out for a beer tonight.
Take him out for a beer?
Yeah. The kid has no life. You're the only guy around here he knows at all. Take him out for a couple of beers, you guys come back, we'll all watch the vote in Leo's office.
Good, thanks. Let me give you some cash.
[puts hand in pocket] Don't be silly.
I have money Mr. President. I'm fine.
Truth be known, I don't have any cash on me.
I don't carry cash anymore. I don't carry keys either.
Well, I wouldn't think you'd need them sir.
Yes sir. [walks back out to the OUTER OVAL OFFICE and turns to Charlie] Charlie?
You don't have to sit with your sister?
She's having a sleepover at a girlfriend's. What do you want me to do?
Tonight. We'll go to a bar in Georgetown. We'll speak as men do.
Um... What kind of bar is this Josh?
Josh, aren't you a little old to be leering at college coeds?
I'm a Fulbright scholar Mrs. Landingham. I don't leer. Also, there'll be plenty of grad students there.
Great. Josh walks out into the HALLWAY. Mallory and Zoey come up from behind.
How do you know I'm going out with Charlie?
He said you should take us with you.
The man is like a camp counselor.
Take us with you, Josh. Take us with you.
We don't care if you flirt with the coeds.
There's gonna be grad students there, can we keep that in mind?
Sounded kinda like an order Josh?
Sam's got enough going on in his life right now without you making a booty call.
I'm not making a booty call. We had an interesting conversation that got interrupted, and I'd like to finish it with him.
This is gonna be fun. Mallory and Zoey leave when Josh reaches his office.
The President's daughter, Chief of Staff's daughter, a Georgetown bar and Sam. What could possibly go wrong? [walks in]

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. and Sam are alone in the press briefing room.

Dialogues.Line: What's the problem with a straight head count?
Head counts have proven staggeringly inaccurate.

How're you gonna count the homeless? There's a large and growing population of people who don't speak English. And there are plenty of people, particularly in the inner city, who don't want to answer questions when you knock on their door. Plus it's always been hard. Sampling, statisticians have told us, is a much more effective way of getting a good census.
The legal argument is it's unconstitutional. The legal argument is it's law.
But if sampling's really against the law, why would congress be trying to pass legislation saying sampling's against the law?
You see how good it feels to understand what you're talking about?
And you see I'm able to do it without being patronizing?
What happened to 'You look good today?'
I'm taking Charlie for a beer tonight before the vote. Zoey and Mallory are coming.
If you want to come... I guess that'd be okay.
Why, Josh, you've swept me off my feet.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby, Mandy, Gladman, Skinner and Willis are still discussing the amendment.

Dialogues.Line: In the last census, 8 million people, mostly black, weren't counted. And in the same census, 4 million people, mostly white, were counted twice.
Sampling will give a count that bears a much greater relationship to reality and will do it to the tune of 4 billion dollars less than a door-to-door head count.
Sampling will cost 2.7 billion. And an inaccurate head count will cost 6.9.
Every single expert, including the census bureau itself, which is a bipartisan commission, has said sampling is better.
We've heard these arguments many times, but in this country we have a constitution.
The Constitution's very clear on this.
Until a court rules that sampling is Constitutional-
Come on, Toby. The article is not arcane.
Let's take a look at it.
No. No. We don't have time-
Let's take a look at it!
Toby! None of us is a Constitutional scholar. And we honestly don't-
My staff managed to unearth a copy.
Toby, come on, we've been here for six-
Mandy, would you read please from Article 1 Section 2?
Still, in all it is the owner's manual and we should read what it has to say!

[reading] 'Representatives and direct taxes shall be apportioned among the several states, which may be included within this union according to their respective numbers. Which shall be determined by adding the whole number of persons including those bound to service for a term of years.'

Well you said it right there. It says which shall be determined by the whole number of persons. The whole number of persons! Not the end of an equation that some statistician got off a computer. It says so right there!
Actually that's not what it says.
Mandy left out a few words. Didn't she Mr. Willis?

Mr. Willis teaches 8th grade social studies, and Mr. Willis knows very well what the article says. It says which shall be determined by adding the whole number of free persons. And three fifths of all other persons. Three fifths of all other persons. They meant you Mr. Willis. Didn't they?

Mr. Willis, you are asking to enact a law, which will limit the ability of those people who need to be counted the most, to be counted as people at all. And they're only refuge is the argument that Article 1, Section 2 is not arcane.
Well, I think we're through here. I can report back to the Chairman of my committee, but I really don't think either he or the leadership is going to allow any one of us to change our vote.
Congressman, you are talking about tying up an Appropriations Bill-
We don't need you to tell us what we're talking about, Toby. And waiting until the 11th hour to call this...
Excuse me! What is this, the 4th time we've arranged this meeting? And by the way it's not...
I think we should drop it.
Joe, Joe...The chairman of our committee recommends that we-
No. I saw what he recommended, and I appreciate his help. But it's still my choice, right?
Absolutely sir. It is your choice.
Well, then I change my mind. I think we should drop the census amendment and let the Appropriations Bill go through as is.
Until a court rules on whether sampling is constitutional.
Well, looks like you snuck one in the back door eh, Toby?
It got through whatever door was open to me.
Well, we're gonna have to revisit this.
Mr. Willis, do you need any help to find your way out?
No thank you. I think I can manage.
Thank you gentlemen. Have a good weekend. Gladman and Skinner leave.
[to Mandy] Go tell Leo. Mandy leaves.
If you don't mind me asking sir, what changed your mind?
Well, I know it wasn't expediency sir. I was wondering what changed your mind?
You did. I thought you made a very strong argument.
Well thank you. [laughs] I'm smiling because, well, around here the merits of a particular argument generally take a back seat to political tactics.
I was taking advantage of you sir.
There are some things I did not mention. First of all, it is partisan. Second of all, I'm not wild about the precedent.
What's to stop us from saying we don't need elections, we'll just use polling data. 1150 people with the sampling error of plus or minus three will decide who runs the country.

It's okay by me. As long as it's not the same people who decide what's on television. Toby, I'm not nearly as smart as my wife was. I went to night school cause I went to work pretty young. And I tried to understand the things Janice brought home from the office, but I wasn't in her league. I never understood what she wanted with a dummy like me. [pause] I think the problems that we're going to face in the new century are far beyond the Wisdom of Solomon, let alone me. But I think the right place to start is to say - fair is fair. This is who we are. These are our numbers.
I'm sorry I never got to know your wife sir.
Nothing to it. They call your name, you vote yea.
Well, this is my first, and likely my only vote in the House of Representatives.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is getting ready to leave for the residence. Mrs. Landingham and Nancy are helping him.

Dialogues.Line: You wanted to read these with dinner.
Would you like the Tokyo Exchange sent to your bedroom?
And the call from the secretary?
Would you like it during the dining room?
I'll take the call wherever I am when he calls, I guess.
There's no need to adopt a tone Mr. President.
I'm not adopting a tone. I'm just trying to get out of here.
Would there be anything else sir?
I'm saying no. I just want to go home.
Goodnight Mrs. Landingham. [to Leo] I heard it's done?
Yeah. Commerce will leave the census amendment in committee. Appropriations will pass, no problem.
Good. I'm headed over to the residence.
I needed to speak to you about something.
I should have told you earlier but... I moved out of the house. Jenny's asking me for a divorce.
Nothing happened, Mr. President. It's just one of those...
Don't tell me nothing happened, Leo. I know you. I know Jenny. Married couples like you don't just get divorced. Not cause nothing happened!
Nothing happened! It's not like that.
I want to talk to Jenny.
I don't understand how this happened Leo. You and Jenny were happy!
Because you weren't spending enough time with her?
Marriage needs attention Leo. It can't run on autopilot. Come on. It's not your prom date we're talking about here. We're talking about your family!
Well, Mr. President thank you for pointing that out. I tried to squeeze in as much time as I could between my wine-tasting club and running your White House.
You can't blame this on me.
I'm not blaming you for it sir. I'm not blaming anyone for it. It just happened, these things happen.
And you're just now telling me?

Honestly, I know how you feel about Jenny. I thought you'd think that somehow you were responsible for it, and you'd turn that guilt into an inappropriate anger toward me, which frankly, I can live without right now. [under his breath] I can't imagine what made me think all that...
[walks over to the door] Fix this, Leo.
It's not as simple as that.
It IS as simple as that. You're the man. Fix it.
Goodnight Leo. Bartlet opens the door and heads toward the residence. Leo just stares at him and stands still.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. GEORGETOWN BAR - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J., Sam, Josh, Zoey, Charlie and Mallory are gathered around a table at a bar. There's a lot of people around.

Dialogues.Line: [to Sam] So, your friend couldn't come tonight?
My friend, of course you're talking about...?
[to C.J.] His special friend that Zoey can't know about.
[pause] Okay...She's not a hooker. She's a call girl. And how do you know about this?
How does Mallory know about that?
You told our boss' daughter that you slept with a call girl?
I didn't know she was Leo's daughter at the time. I thought she was a schoolteacher who came in with her class.
So you thought you were telling a complete stranger that you slept with a call girl?
[quickly] Accidentally slept with a call girl. Mallory, does your father know?
So this is gonna be a thing!
Zoey and I have decided that it's time we start collecting IOU's.
Ah... The waitress places some drinks on the table.
Maybe she just felt really stupid ordering it.
The grasshopper is a perfectly respectable...
[quickly] I want to see them make it. [to Josh] Could you hold these?
Just lipstick and stuff. My panic button. Ruins the line of my outfit.
Make sure they make it extra thick and green. Zoey walks to the bar.
Oh, you don't want to know. I've seen it in action.
The President is a very protective father.
[to Charlie] So, you having a good time tonight?
Seems like you're not really having a good time.
Do you think they know I don't go to college?
Charlie, you're twice as smart as anyone in the room.
Yeah, but I don't go to college.
See, you keep telling him to relax with this sense of urgency...
I just want to make sure he's having a good time tonight.
He's having a good time! You relax!
I'm not being urgent. Meanwhile... Zoey is at the bar when three guys come up behind her, basically surrounding her.
Hey, he's just asking for your name.
Wait. Wait. Why don't we guess your name? All right?
All right, all right. Cause I bet we can guess it. Back at the table...
I wouldn't say that there was urgency in my voice. I was simply asking if he was having a good time, and suggesting that if he relaxed...
Well, maybe if you stopped pestering him like you were his great Aunt Ida...
Excuse me one second. [stands and walks to the bar]
Do you see what I'm saying? Back at the bar...
Cassandra! We were gonna guess. You ruined it.
[coming up] Is everything all right, Zoey?
Hey. He just called her Zoey.
Come on, let's go back to the table.
Whoa. Whoa. Whoa. What's up Sammy?
Zoey? Zoey moves towards Charlie and the guys block her.
Excuse me. Excuse me. We're just trying to buy the girl a drink man.
She's 19 years old man. You'd have to take her to Maryland.
No. Why don't you go? Alright?
Look guys. You don't know who this is. You don't want any trouble. Just be cool alright?
Yeah. I'm just saying, I'm looking out for you.
I understand what you're saying. You just want me to be cool alright?
Can I buy you guys a round?
Like LL Cool J man, like Ice Tea.
Ice cube, Ice tray man. Back at the table...
Why must you mock a perfectly natural brotherly instinct...?
I'm not mocking it Josh, I'm saying maybe if you left the young man alone... Sam has been watching the bar and suddenly heads for it.
[standing] I know. [picks up the panic button and heads towards the bar]
Why don't you do some of that hip-hop for us G-Funk?
Dr. Huffy Puffy dread man, Dr Dolittle Man?
Would you let us by please?
No. What are you doing here with this girl? Huh? Huh? Cause you know what, to me you look to be Dr. Faggot!
[coming up from behind] Hey! What the hell is going on around here?
You want to go? Let's do it. Right now. Come on.
[coming up from behind Charlie] How's everybody doin'?
Oh, this is too good to be true. Mallory and C.J. come up behind Josh and Sam.
[indicating Josh] Hey, I recognize this guy. [indicating Zoey] And she looks familiar too.
Yeah. You guys don't realize it, but you're having a pretty bad night.
Oh really, and who's gonna give it to us huh?

Federal Agents! As Secret Service Agents pour through the door, Josh and Sam raise their arms and point at the three guys near the bar. SAM and JOSH Right here! The agents push the three guys against the bar as another agent ushers Zoey out.
Shut up! I swear to God I'll blow your head off. Everybody stand back.
[to Charlie] Hey, I ain't done with you Sammy.
My name is Charlie Young, jackass. And if that bulge in your pocket's an 8-ball, you'll blow your splendid Spring Break in a Federal Prison. The agents take the guys out of the bar.
[to Josh] NOW I'm having a good time.
[tossing the panic button in the air] Well, my work here is done.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Zoey is sitting on a couch in the White House. Bartlet is standing.

Dialogues.Line: Did you do anything at all to provoke these guys?
Yes Dad, I am 19 years old. I was not flirting with these guys. And even if I was it certainly wasn't justification for their behavior.
I went to the bar to get a drink.
What the hell were you doing drinking?
I was getting a drink for C.J.!
I'm starting college in a month!
Well you'll have plenty of friends to walk you to class.
We talked about this. I'm entitled to this part of my life.
You're getting this part of your life.
The Secret Service should worry about you getting shot.

They are worried about me getting shot. I'm worried about me getting shot. But that is nothing compared to how terrified we are of you. You scare the hell out of the Secret Service Zoey, and you scare the hell out of me too. My getting killed would be bad enough, but that is not the nightmare scenario. The nightmare scenario, sweetheart, is YOU getting kidnapped. You go out to a bar or a party in some club, and you get up to go to the restroom, somebody comes up from behind, puts their hand across your mouth, and whisks you out the back door. You're so petrified, you don't even notice the bodies of two secret service agents lying on the ground with bullet holes in their heads. Then you're whisked away in a car. It's a big party with lots of noise, and lots of people coming and going. And It's a half hour before someone says, 'Hey where's Zoey?' Another 15 minutes before the first phone call. Another hour and a half before anyone even THINKS to shut down all the airports. Now we're off to the races. You're tied to a chair in a cargo shack, somewhere in the middle of Uganda. And I'm told that I have 72 hours to get Israel to free 460 terrorist prisoners. So I'm on the phone pleading with Benjamin and he's saying, 'I'm sorry Mr. President, but Israel simply does not negotiate with terrorists, period. It's the only way we can survive.' So now we've got a new problem, because this country no longer has a commander in chief, it has a father who's out of his mind because his little girl is in a shack somewhere in Uganda with a gun to her head. DO YOU GET IT?!

[long pause] I'm sorry I yelled sweetheart. Forgive me. Honey, I want you to have your freedom and your youth. I want you to have common everyday experiences with girls your own age. But don't ever forget - this is a privilege, and it is an experience that must be cherished beyond measure. And proper protection and security, though at times I admit, it's a drag, is never too high a price to pay.
It's alright sweetheart. It's alright. They embrace. Bartlet kisses Zoey's forehead.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo is sitting on the couch in his office when Bartlet enters.

Dialogues.Line: Hi. Before, when I was being an idiot, there was something I forgot to say.
I would like unanimous consent to revise and extend my remarks.
I don't know what the hell was the matter with me, Leo. If there's anything I can do to help, anything?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh, Charlie, and Sam are sitting around the table.

Dialogues.Line: Let me tell you something, I could have taken the two guys on the left.
The guys on the left as you're facing the bar?
Yeah. No. No. So you're me, and facing toward the bar?
Thank you, Donna. Defending virtue is hungry work.

Yes. As it turns out you actually gave me more money than I needed to buy what you asked for. However, knowing you as I do, I'm afraid I can't trust you to spend the change wisely. I've decided to invest it for you.
That was nice. That was a little parable.
Yeah, so those were my guys.
Okay, there's the one guy with the blonde hair?
There were no two guys that either one of you could have taken. Josh and Sam look at Charlie. Bartlet opens a door and calls.
Yes sir. Josh stands and goes into LEO'S OFFICE.
What were you doing taking my daughter out to a bar?
I told you to take Charlie. When Zoey said she was going I just assumed you were gonna go have malteds or something.
Well anyway. Thank you for doing whatever it was you did.
As a matter of fact, I didn't do anything. But for what it's worth I should tell you that Charlie didn't blink before he put his body between danger and Zoey.
[opens the door] Charlie? Sam, you come too please.
[to Josh] You know, I once played the stage manager in a production of Our Town. Charlie and Sam enter the office.
Charlie, you a good poker player?
Excellent, get your money out and take a seat.
Because I said so. Mandy and Toby enter.
Good evening. TOBY and MANDY Good evening, sir.
Good work both of you. You bought us some time.
I understand you all had a very interesting evening.
He didn't walk into the room with a political agenda. He didn't walk in with his mind made up. He genuinely wanted to do what he thought was best. He didn't mind saying the words I don't know.
I said I don't know to Sam just this morning and I'd like to say I'm a better person for it. By the way, I now know everything there is to know about the census. Go ahead, you can ask me anything.
How many people live in the United States? C.J. could not respond.
There's some material we haven't covered yet. Everyone is now seated at the table except Toby, who is watching the T.V. in the corner of the office.
I just want to watch this.
I just want to hear this one.

Mr. Widen. Mr. Widen of Pennsylvania votes yea... Mr. Wilder. Mr. Wilder of South Carolina votes yea... Mr. Willis. Mr. Willis of Ohio votes yea. Toby lets out a sigh of relief as the roll call continues.
